author: Enviroliteracy Team
title: Are zebra mussels still a problem?
text:
Are Zebra Mussels Still a Problem? A Deep Dive into the Ongoing Invasion Yes, zebra mussels are absolutely still a significant problem in North America and other parts of the world. While initial panic surrounding their explosive spread in the 1990s might have subsided slightly, these tiny invaders continue to wreak havoc on aquatic ecosystems, infrastructure, and economies. Their prolific reproduction, efficient filtration, and ability to attach to nearly any surface make them incredibly difficult to eradicate. The fight against the zebra mussel is an ongoing battle, requiring constant vigilance and innovative management strategies.
The Persistent Threat of Zebra Mussels Zebra mussels, originally hailing from Eastern Europe, were first detected in the Great Lakes in the late 1980s. Since then, theyâ€™ve aggressively colonized numerous waterways across the continent, causing a cascade of ecological and economic repercussions. Their impact is multifaceted and far-reaching.
Ecological Impacts One of the most significant ecological impacts is their ability to filter feed at an astonishing rate. While this might sound beneficial â€“ cleaner water, right? â€“ the reality is far more complex. By filtering vast quantities of phytoplankton and zooplankton , they strip the base of the food web, starving native species that rely on these microscopic organisms for sustenance. This can lead to declines in fish populations, particularly those that feed on plankton during their larval stages.
Moreover, zebra mussels alter nutrient cycling in lakes and rivers. By concentrating nutrients in their shells and waste products, they can create localized imbalances that favor certain algal species over others, potentially leading to harmful algal blooms. They also accumulate toxins, which can then move up the food chain as they are consumed by predators.
Economic Impacts The economic costs associated with zebra mussels are staggering. They are notorious for clogging water intake pipes used by power plants, municipal water systems, and industrial facilities. This necessitates costly cleaning and maintenance procedures, sometimes requiring complete shutdowns. Boat owners also suffer from the musselsâ€™ propensity to attach to hulls , increasing drag, reducing fuel efficiency, and requiring frequent cleaning. Docks, buoys, and other submerged structures are also vulnerable to encrustation, leading to structural damage and increased maintenance costs.
The Challenge of Eradication Despite decades of research and management efforts, complete eradication of zebra mussels has proven elusive. Their resilience, rapid reproduction, and ability to disperse widely make them incredibly difficult to control. Once established in a waterway, they are likely there to stay, requiring ongoing management to mitigate their impacts.
Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs) about Zebra Mussels Here are some frequently asked questions about zebra mussels to further illuminate the persistent challenges they pose:
1. Why are zebra mussels such a concern in North America? Zebra mussels disrupt aquatic ecosystems by altering food webs and outcompeting native species. They also cause significant economic damage by clogging water intake pipes and damaging infrastructure.
2. Will zebra mussels ever go away? While populations might fluctuate in some areas, it is highly unlikely that zebra mussels will ever be completely eradicated from North America. Their adaptability and prolific reproduction make them incredibly persistent.
3. What is the current status of zebra mussels in the Great Lakes? Zebra mussels remain a dominant species in the Great Lakes, although their population densities may vary depending on location and environmental conditions. They continue to exert a strong influence on the Great Lakes ecosystem .
4. Are zebra mussels good for anything? Zebra musselsâ€™ filter-feeding activity can improve water clarity, but this comes at the cost of disrupting the food web and negatively impacting native species. The benefits are generally outweighed by the negative consequences.
5. What is being done about zebra mussels? A variety of management techniques are employed, including settlement prevention , desiccation , mechanical removal , oxidizing biocides , thermal treatments , and biological control methods. Research continues to explore new and more effective control strategies.
6. Why canâ€™t zebra mussels be stopped? Their rapid colonization rate and environmental resilience make them extremely difficult to control. They can attach to almost any hard surface and tolerate a wide range of environmental conditions.
7. What naturally eats zebra mussels? Some predators, such as freshwater drum , round gobies , diving ducks , blue catfish and redear sunfish , consume zebra mussels. However, predation alone is generally insufficient to control their populations.
8. Are zebra mussels OK to eat? It is not recommended to eat zebra mussels. Due to their filter-feeding habits, they can accumulate pollutants and toxins in their tissues, posing a health risk to humans.
9. Will zebra mussels clean a pond? While they can filter particles from the water, introducing zebra mussels to a pond is not a beneficial solution . They can severely disrupt the pondâ€™s ecosystem and negatively impact native species.
10. Why are there no zebra mussels in Lake Superior (or fewer)? Lake Superior is colder and has lower nutrient levels compared to other Great Lakes. These conditions make it less suitable for zebra mussel survival and reproduction.
11. What kills zebra mussels in water? Potassium chloride has been shown to be an effective zebra mussel control agent. Other methods include oxidizing biocides, thermal treatments, and desiccation.
12. How did Lake Waco get rid of zebra mussels? Lake Waco employed a method of smothering zebra mussels with plastic sheeting to prevent reproduction and limit their establishment.
13. What are 3 risks of zebra mussels? Disruption of aquatic food webs: Starving native species. Economic damage: Clogging water intake pipes and damaging infrastructure. Harm to recreational activities: Fouling boats, docks, and swimming areas. 14. How long can zebra mussels survive out of water? Adult zebra mussels can survive out of water for up to a week or longer , and even up to a month under ideal conditions, depending on temperature and humidity.
15. What states have zebra mussels? Zebra mussels have been found in numerous states, including those in the Great Lakes region, the eastern Mississippi drainage, and states such as Texas , Colorado , Utah , Nevada , and California .
Looking Ahead: Continued Vigilance and Innovation The story of zebra mussels is a cautionary tale about the consequences of introducing invasive species. While eradication may not be feasible, ongoing research and management efforts are crucial for mitigating their impacts and protecting vulnerable ecosystems. This includes developing new control technologies, promoting public awareness to prevent further spread, and implementing biosecurity measures to prevent the introduction of other invasive species. The Environmental Literacy Council, at https://enviroliteracy.org/ , is a great resource for further education on this and other environmental challenges.
The fight against zebra mussels is far from over. It requires a collaborative effort from scientists, policymakers, resource managers, and the public to address this persistent threat and safeguard our aquatic resources for future generations. The information presented here is intended to provide a comprehensive overview of the challenges and ongoing efforts surrounding zebra mussel management. By understanding the problem and working together, we can minimize their impact and protect the health of our aquatic ecosystems.

author: TASS
title: Some 250,000 Gaza residents displaced due to hostilities â€” UNRWA
text:
BEIRUT, August 22. /TASS/. Around 250,000 Palestinians from the Gaza Strip were forced to flee their homes due to hostilities, the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees in the Near East (UNRWA) said.
"So far in August, the Israeli authorities issued 12 evacuation orders affecting around 250,000 people in Gaza. Families are repeatedly displaced, carrying what they can amid military operations and summer heat," the UN agency said on the X social network.
Tensions flared up again in the Middle East on October 7, 2023, when militants from the Gaza Strip-based radical Palestinian movement Hamas staged a surprise attack on Israeli territory from Gaza, killing residents of Israeli border settlements and taking over 240 hostages, including women, children and the elderly. Hamas described its attack as a response to the aggressive actions of Israeli authorities against the Al-Aqsa Mosque on the Temple Mount in Jerusalemâ€™s Old City. In response, Israel declared a total blockade of the Gaza Strip, home to 2.3 million Palestinians before the crisis, and has been delivering air strikes on Gaza as well as some parts of Lebanon and Syria. Clashes have also been reported in the West Bank.

organizations.name: united nations relief and works agency for palestine refugees

author: Logan DeLoye
title: Popular Snack Recalled In Massachusetts Poses Life-Threatening Health Risk
text:
ZB Importing LLC recalled six varieties of Ulker Brand snack rolls, biscuits, and wafers" sold in Massachusetts, on February 18th due to the undeclared presence of three common allergens.
According to the United States Food & Drug Administration, the recalled products, distributed to retail stores in 36 states, contain "undeclared wheat, egg and/or milk" which poses the risk of a "serious or life-threatening allergic reaction" to individuals allergic any of the three ingredients not listed on the product labels.
Consumers should avoid Ulker Brand snack rolls, biscuits, and wafers with UPC codes 8690766082307, 8690766086473, 8690504066828, 8690504114628, 8690504067979, and 8690504067986.
So far, there has been one complaint of an allergic reaction reported as a result of consuming the mislabeled Ulker Brand snack rolls, biscuits, and wafers. Officials are urging consumers who have already purchased a recalled roll, biscuit, or wafer to return the product to the place it was purchased for a full refund. Consumers are also being told to throw the item out if it is in their possession.
Concerned individuals with questions regarding the recalled products are encouraged to contact ZB Importing LLC at info@ziyad.com.
For additional information on the recalled products and to see photos, lot numbers, and expiration dates, check out the official recall on fda.gov.

title: Israele pronto a lanciare operazione contro l'Iran Usa in allerta | via personale da ambasciate

Gli Stati Uniti, in allerta, hanno disposto il personale delle ambasciate per garantire la sicurezza, temendo possibili ritorsioni iraniane in Iraq.
